title: Cat. 8  Nude in a Folding Chair, c. 1906
publication_title: Matisse Paintings, Works on Paper, Sculpture, and Textiles at the Art Institute of Chicago
content:
<section class="osci-tk-epub-section tombstone" id="tombstone">Nude in a Folding Chair  
Paris, c. 1906  
Brush and black wash on ivory laid paper, pieced; 66 × 47 cm (26 × 18 1/4 in.)  
Signed: Henri-Matisse (lower right, in pen and black ink)  
The Art Institute of Chicago, gift of Mrs. Potter Palmer, II, 1944.576

</section><section class="osci-tk-epub-section technical_report" id="technical_report">Henri Matisse made this drawing with brush and black wash on ivory laid paper. Although executed in brush and wash, the composition relies on line rather than tone conveyed through passages of fluid wash. The artist extended the sheet by adding a 6 cm strip of paper along the top edge.

The design was drawn directly with brush and black wash and no preliminary guide. Matisse achieved volume in the figure by shading with loose, parallel brushstrokes. Intersecting and overlapping brush marks describe the shape and design of the fabric covering the chair. The deepest black shadows along the figure’s proper left side were built up through multiple applications of discrete brushstrokes rather than solid applications of wash. Repeated parallel lines were also used to distinguish the chair from the background. Matisse used a drier brush throughout, which accentuated the linear texture of the laid paper as the brush touched the high points of the surface and left the interstices white. There is a broad, loose, active quality to the brushed lines that constitute the composition.

The paper strip attached to the top edge was added after the composition was already well developed. All brushstrokes along the top edge of the primary sheet terminate on the deckle edge and do not extend onto the secondary strip (as would be the case if the artist had added the strip prior to starting the drawing). Matisse painted the strip before it was attached. Microscope examination at magnification 80× shows that some brush marks on the strip, such as those to the left of the head, extend under the deckle edge of the primary sheet, which would have been impossible if the pieces were joined first. Matisse used the same type of paper for the addition (the same watermark appears in both pieces). He carefully aligned the laid lines in both papers. Then, probably holding the addition in place by hand, he registered its position with dabs of black wash, bridging the joint to the right and left (see fig. 8.1), and sketched the top of the head on it. The media on both sheets appears to be the same.

With the aid of the registration marks, the sheets were joined using a 1 cm wide strip of dry mount tissue, likely during mounting. The discrete edge of the dry mount tissue extends from between the primary support and the added strip on the left (see fig. 8.2). It has darkened to brown and appears as a linear stain along the joint between the two sheets.

At one point the drawing was dry mounted overall to a white paper mount, now removed, as indicated by a layer of dry mount tissue on the verso (fig. 8.3) with white paper fibers embedded in it. Examination reveals that lines at all edges were cropped when the pieced support was trimmed, most likely in preparation for mounting. Several of Matisse’s smaller drawings from this period are also dry mounted.

Signed: Henri-Matisse (lower right, in pen and black ink) (fig. 8.4).

Brush and black wash.

The support is moderately thick, moderately textured, ivory laid paper. Chain lines run horizontally at 2.7 cm intervals. The laid line frequency is 9/cm. The paper is moldmade. Under ultraviolet light at 254 nm the support exhibits an even, whitish fluorescence from the paper sizing. The primary sheet measures 60.5 × 47 cm. The attached strip, of the same paper, measures 6 × 47 cm with a 0.5–1 cm overlap. The top of the primary sheet is a deckle edge. All other edges were trimmed, cropping the composition. The original dimensions of the primary sheet are unknown, but comparison with similar papers suggests that it is close to its original size.

A watermark appears along the lower right edge: Ingres 1862 (45 × 130 mm) (fig. 8.5). A countermark of a shield with a caduceus and the initials “C F” (6 × 5 cm) appears near the upper right edge (fig. 8.6). There is an identical, partial watermark in the upper left corner of the pieced strip (fig. 8.7). The watermark Ingres, honoring the artist Jean-Auguste-Dominique Ingres, was used by multiple manufacturers to designate high-quality, textured, laid paper intended for drawing. The countermark is the symbol of the paper distributor Catel & Farcy. The date 1862 is not the year the paper was made (Catel & Farcy was established in 1886), and so may hold other significance.

66 × 47 cm (26 × 18 1/4 in.).

There is no record of conservation treatment since entering the Art Institute of Chicago’s collection. Examination reveals that the drawing was once mounted and that the mount was later removed. Lines of the composition are cropped at all edges, indicating that all sides of the pieced support were trimmed at some point, likely in preparation for mounting. There is a discrete layer of dry mount tissue on the verso with white paper fibers from a former mount embedded in it.

There are scattered tan foxing spots throughout, most evident along the left edge, below center. The edges of the sheet have darkened. There is a 5 cm, old, embedded crease in the lower right quadrant, 5 cm from the right edge and 14 cm from the bottom edge. There is a 2 cm tear from the left edge, 13 cm from the bottom edge, that has been mended. There is a 0.2 cm loss to the left edge, 9.5 cm from the top edge. There is a discolored piece of dry mount tissue on the verso of the top edge of the primary sheet. It appears as a dark-brown stain where the two sheets of paper are joined.  
Kristi Dahm

</section><section class="osci-tk-epub-section provenance" id="provenance">Acquired from the artist by Dr. Heinz Braune (born Hans Heinrich Braune-Krickau, 1880–1957), Breslau (present day Wrocław, Poland) and Stuttgart, Germany, by 1922–Oct. 5, 1929.

Sold to Galerie Thannhauser, Berlin, Amsterdam, and New York, Oct. 5, 1929–Dec. 28, 1944.

Sold to the Art Institute of Chicago, Dec. 28, 1944, for $750.

</section><section class="osci-tk-epub-section other_documentation" id="other_documentation">Number  
Location: upper center  
Method: graphite  
Content: 8 (fig. 8.9)

The media and their application, as well as the condition of the artwork, were assessed through visual examination using normal, transmitted, and raking light; microscope magnification (80–300×); and ultraviolet-light examination (254 and 365 nm). The beta radiograph was recorded using a Konica Minolta Regius Σ imaging plate (FP-1S) and a Konica Minolta Direct Digitizer Regius ΣII computed radiography scanner with ImagePilot software set on low–image processing intensity.

</section><section epub:type="footnotes" id="footnotes">The work has had the following titles:

1967: Nu endormi (Jean Guichard-Meili, Matisse: Son œuvre, son univers [F. Hazan, 1967], p. 34,fig. 19; p. 36; 251.)

[ii] The date of this work has been variously noted:

1952: 1906 (E. Tériade, “Matisse Speaks,” ArtNews Annual 21 [1952], p. 44.)

Nine Matisse drawings in the Art Institute’s collection are dry mounted to original mounts: Standing Female Nude Seen from the Back (1900/01; cat. 1), Nude in Profile (1903–04; cat. 4), Boats (1905; cat. 5), Grounded Fishing Boat (1905; cat. 6), Standing Female Nude with Chair (1907; cat. 12), Seated Female Nude, One Foot on a Stool (1910; cat. 13), Standing Female Nude, Twisting toward Her Back (c. 1908; cat. 15), Seated Female Nude, Holding One Knee, with Sketch of a Foot (Aug. 1909; cat. 16), and Girl with a Cat (1910; cat. 17). See “Mounting Evidence.”

Descriptions of paper thickness and texture follow the standard set forth in Elizabeth Lunning and Roy Perkinson, The Print Council of America Paper Sample Book: A Practical Guide to the Description of Paper (Print Council of America/Sun Hill, 1996).

In comparison, Pablo Picasso’s Head of a Woman (1909; Art Institute of Chicago) was made on a sheet with a similar, but not identical, Catel & Farcy countermark. That sheet measures 62.5 × 48 cm, and only the top edge was trimmed (the width is unchanged from the original sheet dimension).

Laid drawing papers watermarked Ingres are still produced today by multiple manufacturers.

Catel & Farcy was one of the largest paper distributors in France at the turn of the twentieth century and contracted with paper mills to produce papers with their mark; see Natalie Coural, Dominique Cordellier, and Hélène Grollemund, Le papier à l’oeuvre (Hazan/Louvre Éditions, 2011), pp. 94–95.

It can be determined that this sheet was produced prior to 1906 because “(FRANCE)” does not appear in the watermark below the shield. It was added in 1906 as a result of U.S. tariff laws requiring the country of origin to be clearly identified in watermarked papers. "Le Secretaire-Adjoint du Trésor, Reynolds décide que les papiers à fillgranes contenant des lettres ou des chiffres doivent porterle nom du pays d’origine” “Douanes Étrangères,” Bulletin-Journal du fabricants de papier, no. 23 [bulletin, vol. 22/journal, no. 52] (Dec. 1, 1905), p. 7.

Galerie Thannhauser, undated collection history; and Zentralarchiv des internationalen Kunsthandels ZADIK, Cologne (Thannhauser stock book 2); photocopies in curatorial object file, Department of Prints and Drawings, Art Institute of Chicago. According to the collection history provided by Galerie Thannhauser, Dr. Heinz Braune was friends with Matisse and acquired the drawing directly from the artist. Braune lived in Breslau in 1921–28, when he was director of the Silesian Museum of Fine Arts; he must have owned Nude in a Folding Chair by 1922, when it was published as belonging to a private collector in Breslau in Roland Schacht, Henri Matisse, Künstler der Gegenwart (Rudolf Kaemmerer Verlag, 1922), p. 62.

Zentralarchiv des internationalen Kunsthandels ZADIK, Cologne (Thannhauser stock book 2); and Board of Trustees Executive Committee meeting minutes, Dec. 28, 1944, p. 3; photocopies in curatorial object file, Department of Prints and Drawings, Art Institute of Chicago.

Exhibition catalogue for Franse tekeningen uit amerikaanse collecties: Van Clouet tot Matisse at the Museum Boymans in Rotterdam.

In this publication, dates of objects given in parentheses do not appear on the work.

There is an indirect reference to Nude in a Folding Chair on page 8 of Joachim’s essay, “Zur Geschichte des Art Institute of Chicago”: “Ebenso schenkte ihre enge Freundin, Mrs. Potter Palmer II, dem Institut gelegentlich bedeutende Zeichnungen.” Nude in a Folding Chair is one of the aforementioned drawings given by Mrs. Potter Palmer II to the Art Institute.

Catalogue for the exhibition The Sculpture and Drawings of Henri Matisse, organized by the Arts Council of Great Britain with the collaboration of the Museum of Modern Art, New York. The exhibition was held at the Hayward Gallery, London, Oct. 4, 1984–Jan. 6, 1985, and the Museum of Modern Art, New York, Feb. 27–May 14, 1985. Nude in a Folding Chair was not in the exhibition.

This was written on the dry mount tissue that was used to mount this drawing and can be read through the translucent tissue.

fig. 8.1 Detail of Matisse’s Nude in a Folding Chair (c. 1906) showing a registration mark in the upper left quadrant used to guide the attachment of the added paper strip. The darkened edge of the dry mount tissue used for attachment appears as a brown line. The Art Institute of Chicago, 1944.576.

fig. 8.2 Photomicrograph from Matisse’s Nude in a Folding Chair (c. 1906) showing the edge of the dry mount tissue. The Art Institute of Chicago, 1944.576.

fig. 8.3 Verso of Matisse’s Nude in a Folding Chair (c. 1906). The Art Institute of Chicago, 1944.576.

fig. 8.4 Detail of Matisse’s Nude in a Folding Chair (c. 1906) showing the artist’s signature. The Art Institute of Chicago, 1944.576.

fig. 8.5 Beta radiograph of Matisse’s Nude in a Folding Chair (c. 1906) showing the watermark from the lower right edge. The Art Institute of Chicago, 1944.576.

fig. 8.6 Beta radiograph of Matisse’s Nude in a Folding Chair (c. 1906) showing the countermark near the upper right edge. The Art Institute of Chicago, 1944.576.
